gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: effects. Explanation: The 'effects' module is a digital sound effects module. It has two main functions, clipping and echo. The module is parameterized by a resolution parameter and it takes in a clock signal, a 10-bit switch signal, and a data input of size determined by RESOLUTION. The output is the processed audio data. A "clipping" operation is performed first which possibly limits the amplitude of the input data based on the value of the first bit of the switch signal (enabling or disabling the clipping effect) before passing the result to an "echo" operation which adds the echo effect based on the second bit of the switch signal. The processed audio data is output after undergoing these digital sound effects.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: data_CLK, SW, data_in. Explanation: 'data_CLK' is the clock signal used for synchronization of the operations within the module. 'SW' is a 10-bit switch signal used to enable or disable the transformations being performed in the module, where the first bit SW[0] is used to enable or disable the clipping operation and the second bit SW[1] is used to enable or disable the echo operation. 'data_in' is the incoming data (of size RESOLUTION bits) to be processed.

Output ports: data_out. Explanation: 'data_out' is the output data post all the transformations (clipping and echo treatment) are performed. This will also be of RESOLUTION bits as the input data. The output data will be echoed and/or clipped based on the switches and the input data.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: L1. Explanation: 'L1' is an internal signal used as a wire with a size of RESOLUTION bits. It serves as an intermediary for the data going between the clipping and the echo operations. It takes the output from the clipping operation 'clipL' and then feed it as an input to the echo operation 'eL'. This signal allows the separation of the two operations and the stepwise transformation of the input data.
